Introduction

Bartholin gland cysts and abscess are a common gynecologic condition characterized by the formation of a painful, localized mass in one of the Bartholin glands, which are located on either side of the vaginal opening.

Pathophysiology



The Bartholin glands (

figure 1
) (ie, greater vestibular glands) are located at the 4 and 8 o'clock positions at the posterior vaginal introitus and have ducts that drain into the vulvar vestibule for vulvovaginal lubrication.



When the ducts of these glands become obstructed, fluid accumulates within the gland, leading to the development of a Bartholin gland cyst.  When the obstructed cyst becomes infected, an abscess forms.  The most common causative organisms in a Bartholin gland abscess are Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, but polymicrobial infection may occur.

Risk factors



Bartholin gland abscess can occur in women of any age but more commonly occurs in perimenopausal women.  Many women have asymptomatic Bartholin gland cysts that are found incidentally.  There are no established risk factors for the development of these cysts or abscesses, but patients who develop them are at risk for recurrence.

Clinical presentation



Most Bartholin gland cysts are asymptomatic.



Patients with symptomatic Bartholin gland cysts typically experience the following:



  • Unilateral pain and swelling near the posterior vestibule of the vulva
  • Dyspareunia
  • Difficulty walking or sitting
  • Mobile, cystic mass behind the posterior labium majus with possible extension to the vagina
  • Possible fluid drainage from the mass


Patients with an abscess have features similar to those of a symptomatic cyst, plus localized erythema and induration and a tender, fluctuant mass.  Fever can occur but is uncommon.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of Bartholin gland cyst and abscess includes:



  • Epidermal inclusion cyst:  a benign cyst that appears as a raised, mobile, flesh-colored nodule sometimes associated with a central punctum.
  • Hidradenitis suppurativa:  inflamed, purulent nodules in the inguinal region that cause draining sinuses and scarring; in contrast to a Bartholin gland cyst or abscess, hidradenitis suppurativa is typically multifocal and painful.
  • Paraurethral glands (Skene glands) cyst and abscess:  obstruction of the paraurethral glands, which can present like a Bartholin gland cyst, but on pelvic examination, the paraurethral glands are located near the urethral opening.
  • Bartholin gland carcinoma:  This type of cancer can present with an enlarging mass; however, Bartholin gland carcinoma typically has a more indolent course, and the mass is usually fixed or has a solid component.

Diagnosis and laboratory evaluation



The diagnosis of a Bartholin gland cyst or abscess is clinical and based on history and pelvic examination.  In cases of abscess, the purulent fluid is collected for culture.  In some high-risk populations, testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis is also performed.



Biopsy of the Bartholin gland cyst or abscess is typically not indicated but should be performed if there is suspicion of malignancy, such as a mass that is fixed or has solid components or persists despite treatment.

Management



Management of Bartholin gland cysts and abscess is primarily with incision and drainage.  This procedure provides immediate relief of symptoms and allows for specimen collection for culture if indicated.  In some cases, a Word catheter (

figure 2
) is placed in the cyst/abscess cavity to form a fistulous tract that improves ductal drainage and reduces the risk for cyst/abscess recurrence.  Antibiotics are typically not indicated but may be used for patients with a high risk for complications (eg, systemic infection, pregnancy, immunosuppression) or for those who have culture-positive, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.



In cases of recurrent abscesses or cysts, marsupialization (

figure 3
) is performed to create a permanent opening for drainage of the Bartholin gland.

Prognosis



Most patients experience rapid resolution of symptoms following incision and drainage.  However, recurrence of abscesses may occur in some cases, necessitating further intervention.

Summary



Bartholin gland cyst and abscess are common gynecologic conditions characterized by the formation of a painful, localized mass in one of the Bartholin glands.  Treatment is with incision and drainage.
